description:
Enterocytozoon bieneusi H348 is a species of microsporidian parasite that infects humans and other mammals. Microsporidia are a group of intracellular fungal-like organisms that can cause opportunistic infections, particularly in immunocompromised individuals.

Enterocytozoon bieneusi H348 is a genotype or genetic variant of the more broadly known Enterocytozoon bieneusi species. It is an obligate intracellular parasite that infects the epithelial cells of the small intestine, leading to diarrheal disease in humans known as microsporidiosis.

The lifecycle of E. bieneusi H348 involves the production of environmentally resistant spores that can be transmitted through the fecal-oral route, contaminated food or water. Once inside the host, the spores germinate and the infective sporoplasm is injected into the host cell, where it replicates and eventually lyses the cell to release more spores.

Molecular studies have shown that E. bieneusi H348 is genetically distinct from other common E. bieneusi genotypes, indicating it may have unique epidemiological and pathogenic characteristics. Further research is ongoing to better understand the prevalence, transmission, and clinical significance of this particular genotype.
